comments.commentBody: Heinous, yes, but "typically liberal"? Have you forgotten that veterans' health, housing, and education benefits were cut under GW Bush?

There's a lot of uncertainty and speculation on this topic. This may be a bit like the concept of "artificial intelligence", which seemed close for decades only to prove more difficult than expected.

Yet it does seem likely this technology will eventually emerge in ways that will transform human life. My great fear, which I hope others share, is that it will be just another way people become tied into networks that serve corporations. After all, this is what is going on these days and there's no reason it shouldn't continue into the area of human computer interaction. Think of the "social network" possibilities! The lucky billionaires.

And the ever present scooping up and manipulation of "data". Only with this technology the "data" will no be in our brain activity. Does that sound good to you?

Within the mind of mankind gods do exist. The question that is not clearly stated here is this; do gods exist within our wavelengths of perception? I can find no supporting evidence so far.  Although, as was stated earlier in this string, evidence may be circumstantial. Even an anti-religionist like myself must admit something...for lack of a better term, mystical (coincidental) appears to happen at times.

"Twenty-one percent of children live below the poverty line" three generations into the "war on poverty" declared by Democrat Lyndon Johnson.
Just how long does it take a person to abandon a failed concept?

Nobody has cut the SNAP (food stamp) program -- more Democratic lies.

All that happened is the Food stamp bill was separated from the Farm bill -- common sense, should have happened 30 years ago.

WIth separate bills, there is more light shown on BOTH bills -- more daylight! -- and actually LESS chance that anyone would dream of cutting or eliminating food stamps.

That being said: the SNAP program exploded in the last 4 years, from covering 7% of the population to now over 15% -- that is unsustainable. We do need to cut back on that "extra 8%" who probably don't need food stamps, or who abuse them (buy junk food or trinkets, or sell their cards for cash).

Republicans may deny reality in the public sphere, but privately, they know exactly what they're doing. As the economy stalls and unemployment remains high, wages will continue to decline, the middle class will continue to shrink and monetary policy will continue to ease - all to the benefit of their funders and really, the only part of their base they represent - the one percent.

They don't mind if our focus is on their crazies like Mike Lee and Louie Goehmert. It's so much easier to rob the middle class and the poor blind when the news media is focused on the "fight" between Christie and Paul, Steve King's ugly immigrant rhetoric and the "threat" of Obamacare. Their mission is to turn over our remaining wealth and resources to the one percent. That's what they're in Congress to do and they're doing a pretty good job of it.

Twenty-one percent of our children live below the poverty line and Republicans cut SNAP. Politicians don't do that because they're crazy. They do it because they're depraved.

I wish I could "Hypothesize" the 20% pay cut in real dollars the furlough is costing me. Interpret this significance -- no saving during the furlough, less spending during the furlough.

and don't forget, we are in Year #1 of a 10-year sequestration. Spend-shy for nine more years.

Welcome to the club. 90% of the jobs being created are contract, temporary and part-time at low-wages. Been that way for the last 5 years. I know plenty of people working 2-4 part-time jobs to cobble together enough to meet the rent and utilities. America is fast becoming a 3rd world nation with the bottom 90% getting poorer by the day and Wall Street getting richer by the day.

Well, mandinka, then you come watch my husband at work. He's a civilian chief of staff for a major command HQ, and he regularly works from 7:30 to 6 p.m., longer if some general who doesn't care about getting home to the family schedules a meeting for 4:00 and then drones on for three hours. And I don't mean he sits in his office and plays computer games from 7:30 to 6:00. He practices Management By Walking Around (when he's not sitting in meetings with generals who have nothing better to do), and is busy kicking those "Feds" who ARE sitting in their offices playing computer games, and waiting for retirement, in the backside. And no, he doesn't request comp time for most of those extra hours; in normal times he was only allowed to ask for six hours max per 2-week pay period, and now with the sequester he can't get any. He does stay away from the office on his furlough days (and it's nice having him home, actually, even with the reduction in pay) but on the other four days he's busy playing catch-up from the day he missed, squeezing five days of work into four. You try it sometime.
Feds not working full time....Having worked with Feds for over 30 years I have never seen one work "Full Time". The title of your article should have been is Feds are receiving less pay
Because Congress works for Wall Street so they are given a pass.

In the private sector they just layoff those they do not need.It would be nice to see a comparison of the wages and benefits of the private sector versus the public sector over the last thirty years. I think it will open a lot of eyes.
Sending people home one day a week is going to increase the cost of the programs they're working on. The sequester is going to end up taking money out of the pockets of each of us.
What kind of fool thinks that getting rid of federal employees' salaries will lead to improving the economy?
You are so right.  I know teachers who are unemployed and haven't been able to find even part time work after moving to a new county or state.
The only thing that could make this "great news" would be if at least 535 of them were our political nightmare called Congress; and that is not the case.

Congress must live by the rules they enact. If government is to be furloughed, they should also be furloughed!

They don't much "work" over a hundred days a year anyway and only attend cocktail parties when in DC as we again pay their first class airfare back to where they came from.

Big waste of money that you and I have to pay for in our taxes!

Josy Will -- the Farm Bill contains a huge amount of money for food stamps and other programs.  Still, it amounts to a direct subsidy of farmers of about 19.4 billion dollars a year.  The budget number you cite is over 10 years with food stamps and other programs included.  Not disagreeing with your point at all, just providing more accurate numbers.
Isn't the Farm subsidy "another out of control Gov't spending bill?
Ever occur to you that food stamps are a subsidy to agriculture? I'll drop food stamps if you raise the minimum wage.

Why is common sense being viewed by Mr. Krugman as being against reality.
i.e. the farm bill should never have been linked to the Food Stamps program in the first place. Farmers grow crops while Food Stamp recipients just receive free money in the form of food subsidies. Democrats liked the previous linkage so they could increase the Food Stamp program at the threat of not passing the Farm Bill.
Well, these threats will never work again since the Food Stamp program will now have to stand on its own and justify why the program is not becoming another out of control Govt. spending program.
They're trying to repeal Obamacare so that the "little people" will never know how (or that) it will benefit them.
The president can't enact a law all by himself, but he can push for it.

Correct. Lyndon Johnson was on the phone twisting arms, wheeling and dealing, and bullying to pass Medicare for days.

Obama sat back and let them duke it out himself. Never one to sully his hands in the muck and mire of actual politics, this guy. He could have used the bully pulpit for the public option.

Instead, as in so many other fights, he decided to throw in the towel before he even got in the ring.

If he has to channel a Republican, it would be nice if he channeled Teddy Roosevelt instead of Bob Dole.

Why can Republicans vote to repeal Obamacare again and again? It must be that the "little people" don't understand how Obamacare benefits them.

Medicare is relatively simple, and people seem to like it.

Obamacare on the other hand has mandates for young people to buy insurance that they don't want, and insurance exchanges. A Princeton economics professor may be able to explain how it works, but the average person can't understand it.

And the complications of Obamacare raise a nagging question: Why is it that the US---supposedly one of the most wealthy nations in the world---cannot afford true universal health care for its citizens? Like, say Canada?

That's what Obama should have pushed for. Instead he watered it down. And now people don't really understand why it benefits them.

And the Republicans play on this again and again and again.

We needed a leader who would push for simple easily understood solutions to basic problems, and then push hard so those solutions were adopted. Somebody like FDR or JFK.

Of course, such a leader might have had to tell an inconvenient truth, like say, we cannot provide universal health care for an exponentially increasing population.

We need zero population growth first, we need to learn to live within resource constraints, we need to increase the number of doctors at the SAME RATE as the population, or universal health care is impossible.

Republicans are not the only deniers of reality.

It's voodoo. It also doesn't speak to the quality of jobs being added or salary levels.

We're not fools, are we?

Although not considered scientific, I have some data....I am a college professor of biology.  I have been following graduates of biology and chemistry for the past three years (roughly 50 per year). Excluding those who are seeking another degree or grad school as a holding pattern move, NONE has a full time job. they are working as lifeguards, attendants at gyms, waiters and waitresses, babysitters, groundskeepers, grocery store clerks,,..you get the picture.  Two of my former students got temporary jobs - one was for 1 week, another for 3.  These kids are on the cusp of the prime working age.  So, consider me skeptical when I see the rosy numbers released lately.

I think a bigger factor than the ones you list are people who are under-employed (taking jobs paying less and less work) then previously.  And many of these people are now contractors, a lot through agencies.  So, their new "careers" are much more dicey, lower pay, less benefits - and there's not really a career path.
And that's not even mentioning that salaries are too low.

OSS Architect and semitech have nailed it. I worked for a company that was bought by a big data company ( the one that had the worst breach of e-mail security in history). A year to the day after the acquisition there was a massive layoff. Prior to the layoff there was a virtual 50-50 split between employees 39-and-younger and 40-and-older. 78% of those released were in the later group. As Stan Lee might say, "Nuff said.

What is the unemployment rate for the 25-54 year old group today? What was it in Dec 2007? Looking at your employment rate numbers, it looks as if that group is at least 4% worse off than Dec 2007. As you suggest it looks like they're doing nowhere.

Added to seeing if employment changes when unemployment benefits end, will suicide rates increase? Will household size increase as a sign of relatives moving in with relatives and friends with friends.

If employers were looking for workers, then wages should rise and hours worked should lengthen. But from the latest jobs report wages went down and work hours shortened. See: July Jobs Report Is Packed With Bad News http://buswk.co/15Aky4y via @BW

Okay, tell me how many Americans are willing to work for 12 hours a day picking tomatoes for a pittance. And how many Americans are willing to buy those tomatoes if the price suddenly doubles or triples because Americans are picking them and demand at least minimun wage, if not more, for 8 hours instead of 12?  And how many (usually well-to-do) Americans would be willing to hire American citizens as household help and nannies if they had to supply higher wages, a health care plan, and Social Security taxes, to get 40 hours a week instead of 60 in return? And just how many illegal aliens are working at fast-food places, where 62% of the new jobs are? Your logic doesn't compute. Most llegal aliens aren't taking away jobs that most Americans want, or can get, because they're illegal, and most (not all) employers do check before they hire.

"American workers do not sent part of their paychecks overseas the same way that immigrant workers do"

As I remember reader in this paper, it is about 7 billion dollars to Mexico alone.

Why doesn't anyone have the courage to admit that ceding a certain percentage of the jobs in this country to illegal immigrants and foreign visa holders guarantees that American citizens will not fill these jobs?

The awful employment numbers that get released every month will continue to stay awful as long as Americans are effectively shut out of what used to be solid blue collar jobs. Illegal immigrants do not push Americans up the economic ladder; they push American masons, and sheetrockers, and framers, and landscapers, and roofers out of the middle class. Save your "no one will pick the crops" for someone else, illegal immigrant farmworkers only make up only 4% of the illegal workers in the country.

The same goes for unemployed Americans in high tech. Companies fall over each other to hire H1-B visa workers and kick American IT workers to the curb. These Americans, especially if they are older, have a nearly impossible task trying to get rehired. And the Senate immigration bill would let more of these foreign workers into the country to grab more American jobs.

Lack of consumer demand is hurting the economy you say? American workers do not sent part of their paychecks overseas the same way that immigrant workers do.

And every month, on cue, the pundit class expresses head-scratching bewilderment about our stagnant jobs picture and the sorry state of our economy. War on the middle class? Mission accomplished!

Monthly job creation over the last 12 months averages 190,000 jobs a month. At that rate we will not recover to 2007 levels of employment till 2021. (NOT A TYPO--2021.) AND that does not even consider higher-paying jobs being replaced with lower-paying ones, and full-time being replaced with part-time. Plug in your own per-month number and see the job-recovery date graph here:
http://www.hamiltonproject.org/jobs_gap/
